principles.name: Fairness as Depth-Forcing Tool
principles.description: 'Fairness is how I get there' because 'you have to enforce fairness in that group' to force them to 'go deeper and not give me their surface-level BS complaints.' This requires them to 'think like an owner.'

principles.name: Owner-Perspective Requirement
principles.description: Fairness enforcement compels people to 'think like an owner' rather than from their narrow departmental perspective, leading to 'recognition of the bigger picture.'

principles.name: Self-Generated Silo Breaking
principles.description: 'If the leaders of the business have a wider lens to look at the business with rather than their own department, then there will absolutely be better decision-making because now we're knocking down some silos without saying that we're knocking down some silos because it has to come from them. Not me.'

patterns.name: Fairness-Driven Perspective Expansion
patterns.description: Use fairness enforcement as a mechanism to force departmental leaders to adopt owner-level thinking and abandon narrow departmental perspectives.
patterns.context: Strategic planning or cross-functional meetings where departmental silos need to be broken down through internal realization rather than external mandate.

patterns.name: Self-Discovered Silo Elimination
patterns.description: Enable leaders to naturally break down silos by developing wider business perspectives, ensuring the change 'has to come from them. Not me.'
patterns.context: Organizational development where sustainable change requires internal buy-in rather than imposed structural changes.

examples.name: Fairness as Anti-BS Enforcement
examples.content: When asked why fairness is necessary, Dan explains it 'forces them to go deeper and not give me their surface-level BS complaints.' This works because fairness requires people to 'think like an owner' rather than from their departmental perspective, leading to 'recognition of the bigger picture.'
